title: 109_hr4929
content: The Act titled "Foreign Investment National Security Review Act of 2006" amends Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 to investigate certain transactions for national security implications. The Act "Foreign Investment National Security Review Act of 2006" amends Section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 to require investigations by the President and the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States for any merger, acquisition, or takeover by a foreign person that could result in foreign control of a US entity engaged in interstate commerce. The investigation must be completed within 75 days of notification. Upon receipt of written notification, the President or designee must investigate any foreign merger, acquisition, or takeover that could result in foreign control of a US entity engaged in interstate commerce. Information filed is confidential and exempt from disclosure, except in relevant administrative or judicial actions. Congress may access the information as needed. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, established by Executive Order No. 11858, is a multi-agency committee comprised of key members including the Secretary of the Treasury, State, Defense, Homeland Security, Attorney General, and Commerce. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, established by Executive Order No. 11858, includes key members such as the Secretary of the Treasury, State, Defense, Homeland Security, Attorney General, Commerce, Office of Management and Budget, United States Trade Representative, Council of Economic Advisors, Office of Science and Technology Policy. The Secretary of the Treasury serves as the Chairperson of the Committee, with other members including heads of federal agencies, the Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs, and the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy involved in investigations as deemed appropriate. The Director of National Intelligence provides intelligence analysis and briefings to the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States. The President must approve any acquisition, merger, or takeover involving foreign persons if it is found not to threaten national security. The Attorney General enforces these regulations. The President directs the Attorney General to seek relief in district courts to enforce disapproval or conditions on acquisitions. All actions under this section are final and not subject to judicial review. Findings of national security impairment are based on credible evidence. The President can direct the Attorney General to seek relief in district courts to enforce disapproval or conditions on acquisitions based on credible evidence of foreign interests threatening national security. Factors considered include domestic production for national defense and the capacity of domestic industries to meet defense requirements. The President can direct the Attorney General to seek relief in district courts to enforce disapproval or conditions on acquisitions based on credible evidence of foreign interests threatening national security. Factors considered include control of domestic industries by foreign citizens, potential effects on sales of military goods to countries supporting terrorism. The President can direct the Attorney General to seek relief in district courts to enforce disapproval or conditions on acquisitions based on credible evidence of foreign interests threatening national security. Factors considered include control of domestic industries by foreign citizens and potential effects on sales of military goods to countries supporting terrorism. Countries of concern regarding missile proliferation, chemical and biological weapons, or listed on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation-Special Country List are subject to these measures. The President must report to Congress any determination to approve or disapprove a merger with a foreign person that could result in foreign control of a US entity engaged in interstate commerce. Congressional action may be taken based on the President's determination. If the President approves a merger, acquisition, or takeover, Congress can enact a joint resolution within 30 days to prohibit it. The resolution would require the President to take necessary actions to stop the transaction, including seeking divestment through the Attorney General in the US district courts. The Congress can enact a joint resolution within 30 days to disapprove the President's approval of a merger, acquisition, or takeover. The President must issue regulations to implement this section, minimizing paperwork burdens and coordinating reporting requirements with other federal laws. The President must issue regulations to implement the approval process for mergers, acquisitions, or takeovers. Technology risk assessments must be shared with relevant parties, and a biennial report on critical technologies is required for Congressional oversight. The President and designated agencies must provide Congress with a biennial report evaluating coordinated strategies by countries or companies to acquire US companies in critical technology sectors and assessing industrial espionage activities by foreign governments targeting US companies for commercial secrets related to critical technology. The President and designated agencies must provide Congress with a biennial report on critical infrastructure, including technologies essential for national defense or security. This report is to be submitted every two years in both classified and unclassified forms. The President and designated agencies must report on critical infrastructure owned or controlled by foreign entities, assess potential coordinated acquisition strategies, and evaluate industrial espionage against US companies. The amendments apply to reviews under section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950. The Defense Production Act of 1950 (50 U.S.C. App. 2170) is being amended to include reporting on critical infrastructure owned by foreign entities and evaluating industrial espionage against US companies. This applies to reviews under the Act that have not been finalized before the enactment of this amendment.
